section-block.rac_essential-question: How can we help plants grow?

section-block.rac_book_summary: It’s hard to believe that a tiny seed can grow into a giant sunflower. Page by page, this book shows how it happens. It also gives us information about what a seed needs to grow into a mighty plant.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: our earth | WEEK 3: Caring for Plants

section-block.rac_body-text: Review with children that plants cover much of our Earth, and that each plant has many parts that help the plant grow.
Invite children to sing and dance to this month’s PreK on My Way™ theme song to build excitement for learning about caring for an important part of our Earth: plant life.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Seed to Plant by Lisa M. Herrington.
Scout is excited to read an informational text and learn about seeds and other plant parts, because he loves eating them!
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What are the parts of a plant?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This page shows a diagram, or picture, of a plant. How many parts can you point to and name?
Inside each seed is a tiny plant that will grow into a bigger plant.
What other living things do you know that start tiny and grow bigger?
Look at this picture and think about what we just read about seeds. Where do you think the tiny roots grow from?
The stem grows straight up. Pretend your hands are leaves and show me how leaves grow on the stem.
These pages are called From Bud to Blossom. Blossom is another word for flower. What does bud mean?
How does this bud look different from the flower we saw earlier?
Look at the life cycle diagram. Point to all the plant parts you know. Where does the life cycle start all over again?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What are the parts of a plant?
section.rac_body-text: Give some time for Turn and Talk. Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share.
Write and read aloud short sentences about how the parts of a plant grow.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Are roots or soil part of a plant?
R_____ (roots) are part of a plant.
Roots are part of a plant.
What kinds of seeds have you seen? Where did you see them?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children love learning about the life cycles. Your children may already be familiar with the life cycle of some organisms, such as butterflies or trees. Help them broaden their understanding, guiding them to realize that all living things go through a life cycle. Ask them to think of other differences between living and nonliving things.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: our earth | WEEK 3: Caring for Plants

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Talk and Share
section-block.rac_body-text: Remind children that when they talk about and share ideas and information, they are exercising an important Mind Builder skill.
Ask how sharing an idea is similar to sharing a toy or a piece of food. Ask children to show what they do when they want to share an idea during circle time or story time.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to think about the talk and share Mind Builder as we revisit the book Seed to Plant by Lisa M. Herrington.
Seed to Plant is an informational text. Clifford loves reading informational texts, then talking about them and sharing ideas with his friends.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we reread, let’s talk about what we learn and share some of our own experiences.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The words in this little box tell us that sunflower seeds have hard cases, or shells. Why do you think seeds need a hard shell? Have you ever tried to eat a seed or nut that had a hard shell? Share with us what you did. (MB)
Who has planted a seed in a pot or a cup? Share with us what you did. Was there soil in the pot? (MB)
Did you notice that the word sunflower has two littler words inside it? What are they? Think about the way a sunflower looks and the way it faces the sun.
Let’s talk about why we think these flowers got their name.
Can you see the tiny pieces of pollen on the bee? Who can share how the bee helps the sunflower’s life cycle? (MB)
Which way are these flowers facing now? Let’s talk about how this helps them drop seeds to the ground. Who has an idea? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Give children an opportunity to talk and share by playing Interview with Plant. Pair up children to play the roles of Interviewer and Plant. Provide each interviewer with a toy microphone. Challenge interviewer to ask three or four questions about the plant’s life cycle, using Who, What, When, Where, Why, and How questions. Let Plant hold the mike when it’s time to answer. Challenge Plants to use information from Seed to Plant in their responses.
Transcribe children’s words as they talk about the life cycle of plants. Ask questions to help them add correct details and revise anything as needed.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: By this time of the year, class rules are well established. Ask children to share the rules for talking and sharing in circle time/story time as well as in small groups. Encourage children to state the rules in a positive way (Raise your hand or Take turns, rather than Don’t interrupt). (Monopoli/Uh.edu, Adventures in Inquiry)

section-block.rac_top-left_header: our earth | WEEK 3: Caring for Plants

section-block.rac_body-text: Tell children an inference is a smart guess they can make using clues in a book and what they know.
Sing to the tune of “Itsy Bitsy Spider”: The sunflower drops its seeds onto the ground/Down came the rain and spread the seeds around/Up came the sun and warmed up all the seeds . . .

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book Seed to Plant by Lisa M. Herrington.
Scout loves Seed to Plant because it gives him ideas about how to take care of his own garden.
This is the question I want you to think about as we read:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What do the parts of a plant do?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions. Have back and forth conversations with children to help them explain how they made inferences as they listened.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Look at this picture. This tall, thin part of the plant is called the stem. How do you think the stem helps the plant?
You can make an inference to answer this question. First, look at the stem again. Then, think about your neck. How does it help you? Put what the book shows with what you know. What is your answer?
We read about a seed on the last page. Do you think the plant in this picture came from one seed or many seeds? Why?

This plant is bigger than a seedling. Do you think that the leaves help the plant to be healthy? How? Think about what helps you to be healthy and add that to what the book says about leaves making food for the plant.
This Fun Fact says, “A sunflower can have 2,000 seeds inside.” Where is inside in this picture?
Did you make smart guesses as we reread the book today? Let’s see as we turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What do the parts of a plant do?
section.rac_body-text: Give some time for Turn and Talk. Then, use Equity Sticks to choose 2–3 children to share.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: A seed grows into a plant.
Leaves make food for the plant.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to write about how a plant grows. Help children add details about each stage of the life cycle.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do flowers make seeds or trees?
Do you think every seed grows into a plant? Why or why not?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Making inferences is a key read-aloud comprehension skill, but four- and five-year-olds will require help to express ideas not stated in the text. Show children how you make an inference through Think Alouds. For example, ask how the stem helps the plant. Then explain what makes you think it carries water from the roots.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: our earth | WEEK 3: Caring for Plants

section-block.rac_body-text: Discuss with children all they have learned about Earth this month and week. What have they learned about plants and how they live?

Sing to the tune of “There’s a Hole in the Bottom of the Sea”: There’s a little seed buried in the ground. Add on until you reach the final verse, There’s a flower from a bud on a stem from a root from a seed . . .

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Jack and the Beanstalk. It is a folktale shown on a poster. Folktales are very old stories.
Scout loves folktales because they usually have magic in them!
Seed to Plant and Jack and the Beanstalk both show a plant that grows. Let’s see if we find any other connections between them.
As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question:
How can we help plants grow?

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Close-Read: Connect to Caring for Plants
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Use these prompts to read and discuss the poster together. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to take turns responding.
This Big Chart is called Jack and the Beanstalk. Can you say the two words you hear in beanstalk?
Why does Jack think he should water the beans?
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show page 9 of Seed to Plant.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Seeds need water, too! Does that mean a bean is also a seed?
Let’s look at the beanstalk that Jack climbed up.
Is it bigger than the biggest sunflower? How did it get so tall?
Why did Jack save the goose? How do you think the giants feel? Describe their faces in the picture.

section.rac_body-text: Divide the class into four groups. Have each group rehearse and perform a different scene of the folktale based on a picture on the poster. Remind children that they can act out the parts of the cow, the beans, the beanstalk, and the goose, as well as human characters.

Provide a writing prompt about the things plants need to grow. Have children generate a list, drawing or writing as many needs as they can remember, based on information in Seed to Plant and Jack and the Beanstalk. Encourage children who are writing to experiment with punctuation marks.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Relational words include words that show location (that is, prepositions) and words that compare things (-er, -est words). These words can challenge English learners. When singing the circle time song, point to a plant diagram to illustrate each relational word (in, from, on) as you sing it. To teach comparisons, use whole phrases (is bigger than).

section-block.rac_top-left_header: our earth | WEEK 3: Caring for Plants

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to act out how they would grow and care for a plant. Encourage them to describe in words the actions they are dramatizing.
Choose a song from Day 1, 3, or 4 to sing again today. Encourage children to move their hands or bodies to act out the words of the song.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book Seed to Plant.
This book is an informational text. Scout enjoys informational texts because he loves learning how the world works.
We’ve read about how a seed becomes a plant. As we read the book one more time, I want you to think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What do sunflowers need to grow healthy and strong?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Listen to the list of what seeds need: water, sunlight, soil, and warmth. Why do you think seeds are planted in spring? Show me how you would plant a seed in the ground in spring.
Look at this young plant surrounded by sunlight and air. Pretend you are a leaf. What are you doing?
The flower bud grows at the top of the stem. Ball your hands into a bud. Now show me how they open up into a flower.
Let’s pretend to be a field of sunflowers that face the sun. Imagine the warm sun on your face. Turn your heads to follow my hand as I trace the sun moving across the sky.
Imagine we are the seeds inside the sunflower. Let’s all scrunch together in the center the carpet.
Now let’s pretend the wind is blowing, and scatter across the carpet!

section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Invite children to turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do sunflowers need to grow healthy and strong?
section.rac_body-text: Pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share.
Invite children to draw or talk about how they can help plants grow. Encourage children to add details to their drawings or their writing.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do sunflowers need from the ground to grow healthy?
Sunflowers need s_____ (soil) to grow healthy.
Sunflowers need soil to grow healthy.
Why do sunflowers need soil to grow healthy and strong?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Preschoolers are just learning that we read print from left to right. Show this by sweeping your finger across text as you read some pages, and explain what you are doing. Many informational texts, like Seed to Plant, include special features like the Fun Fact boxes. Show that these items too are read from left to right.
